bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John Cook Wyllie, October 30, 1947

div1.p: Hench informs Wyllie that he will not have time to carefully choose and prepare Reed materials for an exhibit in connection with Hench's upcoming lecture at the University of Virginia.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John Cook Wyllie, October 30, 1947
div1.opener:
October 30, 1947
Mr. John Cook Wyllie
Curator, Rare Books Division
Alderman Library
University of Virginia
Charlottesville, Virginia
My dear Mr. Wyllie:
div1.p:
I have your letter of October 24, 1947, suggesting that I lend
to your library for display purposes through the month of November cer-
tain materials from my collection of data on the conquest of yellow fever,
in particular, material concerning Walter Reed. I would like to comply
with your request but the situation is as follows: I leave today for a
three-day medical meeting and will return November 3. I will just have
ten days then before leaving for Kentucky November 13 and then on to
Charlottesville, New York and Washington. During those ten days I have
much work to do preparing for meetings and conferences in New York and
Washington; therefore, I am not at all sure that I can spend sufficient
time getting the material ready and writing explanatory notes for such a
display as you might wish. Furthermore, much of my material, indeed most
of it, is of interest only to scholars who already know pretty much about
the whole story and I am not sure how much of it would be of interest to
the casual passer-by. Nevertheless, in order to give you an expression
of my desire to cooperate, last night I spent about three hours very
hastily going through my files and I enclose some quite hastily written
notes which will give you an idea of what I have.

One thing concerns me greatly. I am, of course, aware that
museums exchange invaluable, irreplaceable material, sent by mail or
otherwise but in the present instance I am somewhat fearful about con-
signing any of my material to the mails or railroads, chiefly because I
have had practically no time to copy any of it, nor have I had time to
make more than the most cursory notes from the various letters and docu-
ments which you might wish to borrow. Therefore, if anything should
happen to them, the loss would indeed be irreplaceable. Your letter
mentioned something about the usual methods of sending and insuring such
data but I am not aware of what these methods are. I wouldn't mind
bringing a certain amount of data with me and perhaps leaving it there,
having delivered it myself into your care. My own preference would
be to leave it there until I myself could bring it back; however, I
suppose this is foolish.

Permit me to append a list of the major items I have should you
desire to make a small selection and we could certainly do something
about it. I certainly won't have a chance to copy, photostat or photo-
graph any significant amount of material before bringing or sending it.

By separate post, I am sending you a glossy print of myself
which you have requested and also a reprint of my article in Hygeia and
a mimeographed copy of the talk I gave at the unveiling of the painting
“Conquerors of Yellow Fever” at the A.M.A., 1941, when the painting was
unveiled by Walter Reed's daughter, Blossom. I also enclose a newspaper
clipping which gives a little information on some of the material I
found and as you have requested, I enclose a copy of a biographical
sketch used in Who's Who, brought up to date. I

I expect to arrive in Charlottesville about 10:00 Monday
morning, November 17, and will spend the day with my brother, leaving
Charlottesville for New York that night.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, Philip S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
